Introduction

Streptococcal pharyngitis ("strep throat") is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Streptococcus [GAS]).  It typically presents with acute-onset sore throat and fever, often accompanied by tonsillar exudates.  Diagnosis is ideally obtained via microbiological testing (eg, rapid antigen detection testing), and treatment (eg, penicillin) is primarily for prevention of immune-mediated, delayed sequelae (eg, acute rheumatic fever).

Pathogenesis

Streptococcal pharyngitis is due to S pyogenes, or GAS, a gram-positive, beta-hemolytic bacterium.  It is the leading cause of bacterial pharyngitis and is more common in children and adolescents than in adults.

Transmission occurs via respiratory particles, and pathogenesis involves bacterial invasion into the pharyngeal mucosa.  The cell wall of GAS is studded with M protein, an alpha-helical coiled-coil virulence factor that inhibits phagocytosis, prevents complement binding, and aids in epithelial attachment.  Inflammation of the pharyngeal mucosa results in posterior pharyngeal erythema and tonsillar exudates, and the subsequent immune response leads to systemic symptoms (eg, fever, headache).  Certain strains of GAS produce erythrogenic exotoxins, which are responsible for the characteristic rash of scarlet fever (ie, pharyngitis with a diffuse rash).

Notably, M protein shares epitopes and structural homology with other alpha-helical coiled-coil proteins such as tropomyosin and myosin.  In some patients, the protective antibodies against M protein that develop in an untreated GAS infection may cross-react with myosin epitopes in the heart and cause rheumatic carditis weeks later (

figure 1
).

Clinical presentation

Most patients with streptococcal pharyngitis present between ages 5-15, although any age can be affected.  Classic manifestations include acute-onset fever and sore throat.  Children often have headache, abdominal pain, and vomiting as well.  Symptoms typical of an upper respiratory viral illness (eg, cough, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, mouth ulcers) are usually absent.

Examination findings include the following:

  • Enlarged, erythematous tonsils with exudate (
    image 1
    )
  • Posterior pharyngeal erythema
  • Palatal petechiae (
    image 2
    )
  • Tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy

Scarlet fever

A minority of patients with streptococcal pharyngitis develop scarlet fever, which manifests as a rash in association with pharyngitis.  The rash begins 1-2 days after fever and sore throat in skin folds (eg, armpits, groin) and subsequently generalizes.  It is characterized by diffuse erythema with a finely papular, sandpaper texture (

image 3
).  The cheeks commonly appear flushed, giving the area around the mouth a pale appearance (circumoral pallor).  In addition, the tongue may have inflamed red papillae (strawberry tongue) (
image 4
).  As the illness resolves over a week, desquamation occurs and is most pronounced in the armpits, groin, and tips of the fingers and toes.

Differential diagnosis

Acute pharyngitis

Diagnostic considerations in patients with acute pharyngitis (eg, pharyngeal erythema) include the following:

  • Viral pharyngitis (eg, adenovirus, rhinovirus):  More common than bacterial pharyngitis and often presents in conjunction with upper respiratory tract symptoms (eg, cough, rhinorrhea) and/or conjunctival injection.  Other symptoms suggestive of viral infection include discrete oral ulcers or diarrhea.
  • Infectious mononucleosis (IM):  Typically caused by Epstein-Barr virus and presents with fever, fatigue, and exudative pharyngitis.  Lymphadenopathy typically involves the posterior cervical chains, and symptoms typically last longer than 3-5 days.  Microbiologic testing is often required to differentiate GAS pharyngitis from early IM.

Concomitant rash

For those with a concomitant rash, the following diagnoses should be considered:

  • Erythema infectiosum:  Parvovirus B19 causes a classic slapped-cheek rash (
    image 5
    ) and/or a lacy reticular rash.  A sandpaper-textured rash is not seen.
  • Kawasaki disease:  Fever, rash, and mucosal changes are common.  However, diagnosis requires 5 days of fever and â‰¥4 clinical criteria: >1.5 cm cervical node, polymorphous rash, edema of the hands/feet, conjunctivitis, and mucosal changes (eg, strawberry tongue, dry/cracked lips).
  • Measles:  Classically causes high fevers and diffuse rash.  Tonsillar exudates are not common, and associated symptoms include cough, rhinorrhea, and conjunctivitis.  In addition, the associated rash starts on the face and spreads cephalocaudally, and small whitish/blue lesions on buccal mucosa (Koplik spots) may be seen.
  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease:  Coxsackievirus infection that presents with lesions on the hands/feet (
    image 6
    ) and oral ulcerations.
  • Roseola:  Causes high fever (usually in infants) followed by a morbilliform rash that typically erupts once the patient has defervesced.
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin:  Exfoliative strains of Staphylococcus aureus cause superficial flaccid bullae (
    image 7
    ) followed by extensive exfoliation of the skin.  It is most common in infancy.

Evaluation

Adults

A clinical scoring system (Centor criteria) (

figure 2
) can be utilized in the evaluation of suspected GAS pharyngitis in adults and is primarily used to guide the need for microbiologic testing.  This clinical predictive tool assigns 1 point for each of the following manifestations:

  • Tonsillar exudates
  • Tender anterior cervical adenopathy
  • Fever
  • Absence of cough

Interpretation of the Centor criteria is as follows:

  • Score 0-1:  Low likelihood of GAS pharyngitis.  No testing required.
  • Score 2-4:  Intermediate-to-high likelihood of GAS.  Microbiologic testing for GAS recommended.

Some use 0-2 and 3-4 as cutoffs.  Empiric therapy can be considered with a score of 4 but is generally avoided if testing is available.

Other scoring systems, including the modified Centor criteria (which take age into account), are available.  No scoring system is perfect, but these criteria serve to minimize unnecessary antibiotic use.

Children

Although the Centor criteria are often used in the evaluation of adults with acute pharyngitis, these clinical rules are less predictive in children.  In children, testing for GAS is recommended in those with pharyngitis who do not have symptoms of viral illness (

figure 3
).

Diagnosis

For both children and adults, the diagnosis of streptococcal pharyngitis should be made via one of the following microbiologic tests of a swabbed specimen of the tonsils and posterior pharynx.

Rapid antigen detection testing

This immunoassay, which is first-line for diagnostic testing, detects GAS antigens and provides in-office results within minutes.  The test has high specificity (â‰¥95%) but relatively low sensitivity (as low as 70%).

Throat culture

Samples are plated on blood agar and evaluated for beta-hemolysis within 48 hours.

In adults, the incidence of streptococcal pharyngitis as well as its complications (eg, acute rheumatic fever) are lower compared to the incidence in children; therefore, a negative rapid antigen test is sufficient to exclude the diagnosis.  However, a negative rapid antigen test in a child should be confirmed with a throat culture.

Testing for scarlet fever is identical to testing for streptococcal pharyngitis.

Complications

Suppurative (acute, direct extension of GAS)

  • Peritonsillar abscess (
    figure 4
    ):  Infection between the tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles.  Characteristic findings include sore throat, fever, muffled voice, trismus and unilateral swelling of the posterior pharynx with uvular deviation; most patients are adolescents.  The treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics and abscess drainage.
  • Retropharyngeal abscess (
    figure 5
    ):  Infection of the fascial space between the pharynx/esophagus and vertebral bodies.  Symptoms include odynophagia, fever, neck stiffness, and a muffled voice; most patients are age <5.  The treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics and close observation for acute airway obstruction; surgical drainage may be indicated for large or refractory abscesses.
  • Otitis media:  Middle ear space infection.
  • Sinusitis:  Paranasal sinus infection.
  • Cervical lymphadenitis:  Unilateral anterior cervical lymph node infection (eg, erythema, warmth, Â± fluctuance).

Nonsuppurative (immune-mediated, delayed sequelae)

  • Acute rheumatic fever (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  Multisystem, autoimmune disease that can develop 2-4 weeks after untreated GAS pharyngitis.  It most commonly affects children and adolescents with major manifestations including arthritis, pancarditis, Sydenham chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.
  • Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  Complication of infection with nephritogenic strains of GAS that is not preventable with antibiotic therapy.  It occurs due to immune complex deposition on the glomerular basement membrane and typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria (variable), edema, hypertension, and oliguria with low C3 and CH50 levels.

Prognosis and management

Untreated GAS pharyngitis typically resolves within 3-5 days.  However, a 10-day course of oral penicillin V or amoxicillin is first-line treatment for all patients with streptococcal pharyngitis for the following benefits:

  • Prevention of acute rheumatic fever
  • Prevention of suppurative complications (eg, peritonsillar abscess)
  • Prevention of spread to close contacts
  • Decreased symptom severity and duration (when started within 2 days of symptom onset)

Patients who have a penicillin allergy can receive cephalexin (mild reactions) or azithromycin (severe, IgE-mediated reactions).  Additional management includes supportive care (eg, adequate fluid intake and analgesics).

Management of scarlet fever is the same as that of streptococcal pharyngitis.

Summary

Streptococcal pharyngitis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
) caused by group A Streptococcus (GAS) classically presents with abrupt-onset sore throat and fever, often with tonsillar exudates on examination.  Diagnosis is ideally confirmed via rapid antigen detection testing for GAS or throat culture, and first-line treatment is a 10-day course of penicillin or amoxicillin.  Acute rheumatic fever is a complication of untreated GAS pharyngitis, whereas poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis can occur despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.
